intro: Dysphania bonariensis, commonly known as New Zealand spinach, is an annual herbaceous plant native to South America. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its smooth, succulent leaves that are edible and often used in cooking. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with branched stems that are covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small, yellow, and clustered in dense inflorescences, which appear in the axils of the leaves. Dysphania bonariensis thrives in warm climates and is often cultivated as a leafy vegetable due to its nutritional value and mild flavor.
